since in the future if you wish to update to a newer revision of the game and lets say jagex decides to change all item id’s it will be a big hassle to change the item id’s in all classes for all skills, better make all items like


Tf? Why the hell would they change all the item id. It's just too much pointless work...

etc…

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Oh I forgot to comment on Strucker saying to not use full word constants.
Mate, it’s my code, and my programming style. With my style I tend to name things rather, well full. Like constants for example, I like to name (if an item or object) public static final int DRAGON_SCIMITAR or public static final int OAK_TREE. It’s just how I name things. Don’t like my naming? change it if/when you use my code.

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Strucker:

Knock off the full word in constants, and nice to see ur using enum, but did you really have to make a new class for it?

This is a bump on a old ass topic, but it’s still usable.

I don’t think it would have mattered if I put the enum in the same file as the actual runecrafting class instead of having it in a sepreate data class. I did it like this because I like to have the skill data in one area and the skill handlers in another. Yes, while that’s probably a bad technique, it makes it easier for me to modify the skills (like xp gained per rune crafted and etc) without digging through some code.

Again, it’s done based on my personal preference. If you don’t like it, then put the enum wherever you want it.

[hr]
Note to anyone replying:
I cannot modify the OP anymore whatsoever, therefore I will not be attempting any updates to the thread.

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Besides, I’m sure this base is for a specific version of Runescape. Chances are, the dev on the project will probably rebuild at some point, and changing two ids is no big issue. I suppose, if you wanted it to be more dynamic, you could load it in an external, local file, and then you’d just have to restart the server, but like arham said, that’s a future problem. You can’t account for everything.

public class Server {

    public void onLoad() {
        // ...
        loadRunecrafting();
    }

    private void loadRunecrafting() {
        parseRunecraftingConfigData();
        // register object handlers, item handlers, etc.
    }

    private void parseRunecraftingConfigData() {
        XMLDocument doc = XMLDocument.load("runecrafting_module.xml");
        final int runeEssenceId = (int) getConstantValue(doc, "rune_essence");
        final int pureRuneEssenceId = (int) getConstantValue(doc, "pure_rune_essence");
        // etc
    }
}
<module name="Runecrafting Constants">
    <constant name="rune_essence" type="integer">1436</constant>
    <constant name="pure_rune_essence" type="integer">7936</constant>
</module>

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“sspoke, post:10, topic:536655”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=655468.msg4389241#msg4389241 date=1386875464]

a good server wouldn’t even have

public static int PURE_ESS = 7936;
public static int RUNE_ESS = 1436;

since in the future if you wish to update to a newer revision of the game and lets say jagex decides to change all item id’s it will be a big hassle to change the item id’s in all classes for all skills, better make all items like

public static int RUNE_ESSENSE= 7936;

etc…

in one big ItemConstants.java or something then you just do

ItemConstants.RUNE_ESSENSE

so in the long run you just have to modify one file to fix all item id’s up.
same should be applied to ObjectConstants.java

ObjectsConstants.NORMAL_TREE
ObjectsConstants.DOOR
ObjectsConstnats.IRON_ORE

etc…

That is just as bad.

I rather do
Item: [size=10pt]if(item.equalsIgnoreCase(“rune essence”) { /* do something * /}[/size]
Objects:[size=8pt] if (object.equalsIgnoreCase(“tree”) { /* do something * / }[/size]

That way you’re using less memory and are not creating any unneeded objects.

Edit:
public static int PURE_ESS = 7936;
public static int RUNE_ESS = 1436;

Those are not even constants, why is everything static?

[/quote]

Haha even

item.equalsIgnoreCase("rune essence")

what if they change the name of the item/object in the future lol, but thats just going crazy lol.
But yeah I also did it the string way to include all the doors/ladders without including all id’s for making the changing depth work, but still even though it’s simple it will create problems which you will either patch by adding a quick fix patch like a array of doors/ladders that won’t work without having some quest complete or something etc… when the right way of doing this is making definitions for each item/object in one area so you can see all the triggers/purposes of all items in one file whether its xml file or whatever, even runescape does this in their cache each item has properties such as stackable/price etc… not as much as serverside has but same thing.

ya as for constants they should be with a final modifier so you can’t alter them but really no one would edit them anyways who cares in the long run.

@sk8rdude461: ya i’m just writing some criticism i know you did a good job anyways, maybe someone reading this will incorporate what i said into their servers etc… and other good ideas people write and everything will just get better.[/quote]
Future’s problem, not ours.

Read full topic

in one big ItemConstants.java or something then you just do

That is just as bad.

I rather do
Item: [size=10pt]if(item.equalsIgnoreCase(“rune essence”) { /* do something * /}[/size]
Objects:[size=8pt] if (object.equalsIgnoreCase(“tree”) { /* do something * / }[/size]

That way you’re using less memory and are not creating any unneeded objects.

Edit:
public static int PURE_ESS = 7936;
public static int RUNE_ESS = 1436;

Those are not even constants, why is everything static?
[/quote]

Haha even

item.equalsIgnoreCase("rune essence")

what if they change the name of the item/object in the future lol, but thats just going crazy lol.
But yeah I also did it the string way to include all the doors/ladders without including all id’s for making the changing depth work, but still even though it’s simple it will create problems which you will either patch by adding a quick fix patch like a array of doors/ladders that won’t work without having some quest complete or something etc… when the right way of doing this is making definitions for each item/object in one area so you can see all the triggers/purposes of all items in one file whether its xml file or whatever, even runescape does this in their cache each item has properties such as stackable/price etc… not as much as serverside has but same thing.

ya as for constants they should be with a final modifier so you can’t alter them but really no one would edit them anyways who cares in the long run.

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Arcik:

Those are not even constants, why is everything static?

Essentially all skills should be static as nothing changes besides what item(s) you’re using.

Edit:

[quote=“sspoke, post:6, topic:536655”]a good server wouldn’t even have

public static int PURE_ESS = 7936;
public static int RUNE_ESS = 1436;

since in the future if you wish to update to a newer revision of the game and lets say jagex decides to change all item id’s it will be a big hassle to change the item id’s in all classes for all skills, better make all items like

public static int RUNE_ESSENSE= 7936;

etc…

in one big ItemConstants.java or something then you just do

ItemConstants.RUNE_ESSENSE

so in the long run you just have to modify one file to fix all item id’s up.
same should be applied to ObjectConstants.java

ObjectsConstants.NORMAL_TREE
ObjectsConstants.DOOR
ObjectsConstnats.IRON_ORE

etc…[/quote]

I used what I did because I wrote this generally for most PI servers, and most PI’s do not have a feature as such. So even if I were to have some class like that, I wouldn’t of put that in this snippet.

Read full topic

Constants are static because they don’t need to belong to the class. When you use a constant It applies for everything. So the item id of a pot is 1976 for all the players.

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:2, topic:536655”][code=java] public static int getRuneMultiplyer(Client c, int runeId){
switch(runeId){
case 553://Body
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 46;
case 554://Fire
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 35;
case 555://Water
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 19;
case 556://Air
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 10;
case 557://Earth
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 26;
case 558://Mind
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 14;
case 561://Nature
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 91;
case 562://Chaos
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 74;
case 564://Cosmic
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 59;
case 9075://Astral
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 82;

            }
            return 1;
    }[/code]

I haven’t look at all of your code but this can be shortened. Why not add what you want to divide it by to the enum.

public static int getRuneMultiplyer(Client c, int runeId){ for(Enum e : Enum.values()) { if(runeId == e.getId()) { c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / e.getDividedBy(); } } } }

This is done pretty horribly but for your first time using an enum you did okay.[/quote]
I didn’t think to do it that way honestly. I was writing it rather fast and this just seemed simple to me. I’ll have to update the code. Thanks for the feedback.

Read full topic

return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 10;
case 557://Earth
return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 26;

return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / 14;

            }

I haven’t look at all of your code but this can be shortened. Why not add what you want to divide it by to the enum.

public static int getRuneMultiplyer(Client c, int runeId){ for(Enum e : Enum.values()) { if(runeId == e.getId()) { c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / e.getDividedBy(); } } } }

This is done pretty horribly but for your first time using an enum you did okay.

item.title: [PI] RuneCrafting - My first enum-based skill
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

I’ve finally made something that uses enums. It’s still probably shitty but here you go.

I’m not explaining this shit because it’s a snippet.

Yes, this supports multiple runes, and requires you to have pure ess to make some runes (look in RuneData to change that).

Runecrafting.java

[code=java]
package server.model.players.skills.Runecrafting;

import server.Config;
import server.model.players.Client;
import server.util.Misc;

public class Runecrafting extends RuneData {

public static final int PURE_ESS = 7936;
public static final int RUNE_ESS = 1436;


public static void craftRunes(Client c, int objectId, int playerLevel, int essId){

	for (final RCData r : RCData.values()) {

		if (objectId == r.getObjectId()) {

			if(r.getRequiredLevel() > c.playerLevel[20]){
				c.sendMessage("You need "+r.getRequiredLevel()+" to craft "+
						c.getItems().getItemName(r.getRuneId())+"s.", false);
			} else {
				
				if(r.getEssId() == PURE_ESS && !c.getItems().playerHasItem(PURE_ESS)){
					c.sendMessage("You need Pure Essence to craft runes at this altar.", false);
				}
					
				int itemToDelete = 0;
				int itemToDelete2 = 0;
				if(r.getEssId() == RUNE_ESS){
					if(c.getItems().playerHasItem(PURE_ESS) && c.getItems().playerHasItem(RUNE_ESS)){
						itemToDelete = PURE_ESS;
						itemToDelete2 = RUNE_ESS;
					}else if(c.getItems().playerHasItem(PURE_ESS))
						itemToDelete = PURE_ESS;
					else if(c.getItems().playerHasItem(RUNE_ESS))
						itemToDelete = RUNE_ESS;
					else{
						c.sendMessage("You need Rune Essence to craft runes at this altar.", false);
						return;
					}
				} else if (r.getEssId() == PURE_ESS)
					itemToDelete = PURE_ESS;
				
				int amount = c.getItems().getItemAmount(itemToDelete+itemToDelete2);
				int exp = (r.getExpGain() * amount)* Config.RUNECRAFTING_EXP;
				int amountToCraft = amount * getRuneMultiplyer(c, r.getRuneId());
				
				if(amountToCraft == 0)
					amountToCraft = amount;
				
				//Subtract the opposite itemToDelete so it doesn't attempt to take more than the player has.
				c.getItems().deleteItem(itemToDelete, amount-itemToDelete2);
				if(itemToDelete2 != 0)
					c.getItems().deleteItem(itemToDelete2, amount-itemToDelete);
				c.gfx0(186);
				c.startAnimation(791, 0);
				c.getPA().addSkillXP(exp, 20);
				c.sendMessage("You craft "+ amountToCraft +" "+c.getItems().getItemName(r.getRuneId())+"s.", true);
				c.getItems().addItem(r.getRuneId(), amountToCraft);
				c.saveCharacter = true;
			}
		}else {}
	}
}

public static int getRuneMultiplyer(Client c, int runeId){
	for(final RCData r : RCData.values()) {
		if(runeId == r.getRuneId()) {
			if(r.getDivide() != -1){
				return c.getPA().getLevelForXP(c.playerXP[20]) / r.getDivide();
			}
			return 1;
		}
	}
	return 1;
}

public static void handleZMI(Client c){
	int essAmount = 0;
	
	int[] possibleRunes = {
		554, 555, 556, 557, 558, 559, 560,
		561, 562, 563, 564, 565, 566, 9075
	};
	
	if(!c.getItems().playerHasItem(PURE_ESS)){
		c.sendMessage("You need Pure Essence to use this altar.", false);
		return;
	}
	
	essAmount = c.getItems().getItemAmount(PURE_ESS);
	
	c.gfx0(186);
	c.startAnimation(791, 0);
	
	int[] runesToGive = new int[essAmount];
	int[] amountToGive = new int[essAmount];
	int[] expToGive = new int[essAmount];
	
	/*
	 * Calculating what runes you'll get and how many
	 */
	for(int i = 0; i < 28; i++){
		if(essAmount > 0 && i <= runesToGive.length-1){
			runesToGive[i] = possibleRunes[Misc.random(possibleRunes.length-1)];
			amountToGive[i] = Misc.random(essAmount);
			essAmount -= amountToGive[i];
		}else
			continue;
	}
	
	/*
	 * Calculating the XP gained from the runes (It's doubled because of the ZMI altar's effect.
	 */
	for (final RCData r : RCData.values()) {
		for(int q = 0; q < runesToGive.length-1; q++){
			if(runesToGive[q] == r.getRuneId())
				expToGive[q] = (((r.getExpGain() * amountToGive[q])*Config.RUNECRAFTING_EXP)*2);
		}
	}
	
	/*
	 * Removing the pure ess and adding the runes in place
	 */
	for(int j = 0; j < runesToGive.length-1;j++){
		c.getItems().deleteItem(PURE_ESS, amountToGive[j]);
		c.getItems().addItem(runesToGive[j], amountToGive[j]);
		c.getPA().addSkillXP(expToGive[j], 20);
	}
}

}[/code]

RuneData.java

package server.model.players.skills.Runecrafting;

public class RuneData {

	public enum RCData {
		AIR(2478, 1, 5, 1436, 556, 10),
		MIND(2479, 2, 6, 1436, 558, 14),
		WATER(2480, 5, 6, 1436, 555, 19),
		EARTH(2481, 9, 7, 1436, 557, 26),
		FIRE(2482, 14, 7, 1436, 554, 35),
		BODY(2483, 20, 8, 1436, 553, 46),
		COSMIC(2484, 27, 8, 7936, 564, 59),
		CHAOS(2487, 35, 9, 7936, 562, 74),
		ASTRAL(17010, 40, 9, 7936, 9075, 82),
		NATURE(2486, 44, 9, 7936, 561, 91),
		LAW(2485, 54, 10, 7936, 563, -1),
		DEATH(2488, 65, 10, 7936, 560, -1),
		BLOOD(30624, 77, 11, 7936, 565, -1);

		private int objectId, requiredLevel, expGain, essId, runeId, divideBy;
		
		private RCData(int objectID, int requiredLevel, int expGain, int essId, int runeId, int divideBy){
			this.objectId = objectID;
			this.requiredLevel = requiredLevel;
			this.expGain = expGain;
			this.essId = essId;
			this.runeId = runeId;
			this.divideBy = divideBy;
		}

		public int getObjectId() {
			return objectId;
		}

		public int getRequiredLevel() {
			return requiredLevel;
		}

		public int getExpGain() {
			return expGain;
		}

		public  int getEssId() {
			return essId;
		}

		public  int getRuneId() {
			return runeId;
		}

		public  int getDivide() {
			return divideBy;
		}
	}
}

Read full topic
